posts.author: HipRedux
posts.content:
Let me be the first to welcome you to our guild (unless I get ninja'd), Benzinh!   We are glad you found us.

Yeah, I've seen this done at least once for server play but can't recall if it was here, the BSN or some other forum like WoG or HG.  The Light Saber build.  It may have been a DW.  Dunno atm.

If I am understanding you... all you want out of the monk class is some quick feats, WIS synergy AC, perhaps some extra speed and universal high saves.  You'll be missing out on the sweet -3BAB monk progression of course (without using kama, that is) but RP always tends to have its trade-offs.  I would highly recommend going with exotic prof/katana only because many have lauded how excellent the weapon appearance is in-game compared to other sorts.  It probably is the closest facsimile of a light saber IMO.  But whatever floats your boat...

Monk will be your main skill dump class I guess.  Then either fighter, pally or cleric depending on if WM is practical or not in a limited cap environment.  Maybe SD HiPS a possibility for that matter. 

But before getting ahead of ourselves, I suggest you furnish some of the request essentials like the approximate cap (this will determine what level to optimize your build for). 1-20 or 1-40 coincides with very few modules or series and it is usually best to craft abuild for the exact expected cap (eg. OC Lvl 18, SoU/HotU Lvl 28).  If you are planning to play several different modules, caps will all be different.  Apologies, but I have no clue what a "DLC" is so you will need to explain.  Typically, the OC is played with one toon, then SoU/HotU (with or without a bridge module) with another, and then each of the premiums with their own.  Or are you referring to playing CC (Community Content)? No matter.  Each of those has different caps and features.

Rather than ending up with a mish-mash of ideas that may not be all that effective, how about settling on a single campaign or campaign combo and then face each other build as you encounter them.  I seriously doubt that any single "one-size-fits-all" build will service your multi-layered request equally.

BTW, your English writing seems fine to me.  Don't anticipate any problems there.

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content: As Hip already mentioned, the OC covers levels 1 - 18, and SoU + HotU cover levels 1 - 28. Those are fun to play, and the OC is great for learning how to play the game, but don't limit yourself to just those. For me, the biggest appeal of NWN is the huge library of user-made modules to download and play. For example, after you finish HotU at level 28, take that character into the Sands of Fate series to go the rest of the way to level 40. The Aielund Saga (levels 1 - 36) is awesome, and it would be great for that katana build that Hip mentioned.

posts.author: HipRedux
posts.content:
This should work for the OC.  You'll get a 20% XP penalty on the final 2 levels (assuming you reach that far) but that can't be helped without prestige classes.  CoT requires a "throw-away" feat to get the focus (either martial/scimi or exotic/katana).  You could go with your scimi and save a feat but TBH I don't know what feat is a game-breaker since Monk 1-6 with give Cleave, KD and IKD.  Maybe Expertise... but for BAB 14@Lvl 18, opportunities to get much out of -5 AB are few and far between.  In epic, you could go to DevCrit with this build though it would take a long time, probably very late with lots of Grt STR and fewer cleric levels.

You should understand that your WIS>14 CHA>12 prereq seriously gimps the build potential but such are the trappings of RP, eh?

You should be getting something like +6 AB with your buffs (some divine), another +2 per GMW if you can't find better than +2 weapon, which I am sure you will in the OC.

You'll get 5 turn attempts for DS/DM boosts, 8 with Emp Eagle and 13 with capped CHA... per day.  Duration will range from 2 to 8 rounds depending on buffs/gear.

At cleric 8, you will get empowered abilities and extended Prayer/Bless/Aid but, alas, no Battletide (which I love).  I would expect in an epic version to pump cleric to at least 15 for buff duration and universal buff caps, if nothing else. Plan on investing in all the +WIS gear you can find since you will be needing lots of pre-buff slots plus it will boost your AC. Domain choice is a tough call. Trickery seems worthwhile, but would need at least Clc 9 to use ImpInvis so really not worth it unless you vest in traps/locks.  Perhaps in SoU/HotU that would be a better choice. I like Magic for Mage Armor/Stoneskin.  Strength Stoneskin doesn't occur until Clc 9 so that is out. Maybe Plant for Barkskin but there are loads of Barkskin pots in the OC and the Plant version will only net +1 Nat AC over those. CD is way beyond the scope of a Lvl 18 build. Strength seems automatic to me for a pre-epic BAB less than 16.  War domain good for a Dexer but AoV is also beyond this build.

Note that nothing but a Dexer can use stealth effectively but since STR is your default choice, so be it. You'll have 25 skill points to spread around as non-combat skills of your choice.  Enjoy!

So, anyway, review and comment...

posts.author: HipRedux
posts.content:
Benzinh wrote:
Ty for your answer Hip this build is really fit my expectations however I was a bit incorrect with this WIZ>14 CHA>12 restriction by that i meant not less than 14 and 12 respectively. So I think it would be 16 WIS 12 CHA and 10 DEX or invest more in STR?
 
It's not as bad as all that really.  What the elevated CHA did for my attempt was open up DivMight/DivShield for a monk which is quite uncommon but effective nonethless.  I would expect that, combined with WIS AC and cleric AC buffs, this AC could reach very high levels.
 
Now, as to Divine Power... the way it automatically raises STR to 18 is worthless in a STR build but the additional full BAB attack works well.  Usually, DP is part of a DEX build but still can be effective in this case.

What you will be aiming for is Monk 20/Cleric 15/Fighter5 in the epic version so figure on 2 more points to WIS for Level 8 slots. 

Clerics can make up very well for any lack of gimped (less than 30) primary ability to boost AB on it's own.  It's the main feature of that class.  In most cases, you should be able to reach the +20 AB cap by combining weapon enhancement, buffs and reaching ability cap (in this case, +12 STR).  Your in-game AB should be in the same ballpark as a WM, in the 50's somewhere.  A key bonus with divine AB is that it can penetrate all DR, damage resistance and damage immunity.

I'd leave the ability spread "as is" for the moment. 
So I can't reach level 40 with all diamond edition content and have to use some player created modules?
Ahhh...  I see what you were considering now.  You thought you could just string all the Bioware modules together, one after another, to reach level 40.  A common mistake by new players.  No worries. 

The fact is: Each BW module (except for HotU) has been designed for a starting toon.  That means that killing hostiles to gain experience relies on something called CR (Challenge Rating) of each foe.  The higher the CR, the more XP you will get.  But all the modules have set creatures at a very low CR for starting toons and increase CR slowly.  Therefore, as you continue to start a new BW module with a high-level PC, you will get the minimum XP (which, as I recall, is 4 XP per kill solo) so will gain so little to complete the module it becomes just tedious.  There will be NO challenge at all and no fun for Jedi or Sith.  Quest rewards are the same, but still are a minor portion of the overall XP tally per module.

To reach level 40 (and even beyond into legendary levels up to 60), you need to either play custom content that has designed high-CR encounters into it or play on a PW (or LAN).  Players like me usually play SP content without caring how high level can be reached and, if the build seems to be working well, start the same build over on a challenging PW.  SP serves more like a practice area for me where one can save the game and then pick up where you left off.  Some SP can be very challenging, so look for those that have limited rest opportunities and serious death penalties.  Conditions like that will mimic those found on most competitive PWs and will make you a better all-around player.
How this build will look at epic levels or it would be better to go different one? Probably replace fighter with CoT to get rid of xp penalty?
I stated previously the final class split I had in mind.  To qualify for CoT, you would need to take a "throw-away" feat like WF: kama just to open up CoT and then take WF: katana. The XP penalty can be minimized to a handful of levels for most of the build so, IMO, not all that much of a deterrent.

Besides that, CoT requires BAB+7 which will take much of pre-epic to reach with 3/4 BAB classes (Clc/Mnk).  The sacred defense saves would help, naturally, but with only 5 levels open, hardly worth the effort.  In a CoT-heavy build, a sacrificial feat would be easier to reconcile. When building toons, feats are GOLD!

In this build, though, I am focusing on building BAB as quickly as possible for playability at early levels.  Also, getting EWF/EWS on a single epic fighter level allows you to reach monk's 50% concealment and immunity to mind spells (not to mention a katana-wielder with glowing blue eyes) with the classic Cleric 15 buff optimization.

posts.author: HipRedux
posts.content:
Benzinh wrote:
Hip what do u think about paladin class instead of cleric? Saving throws, imunes and even holy sword as "light saber"? Something like 15 pal/1 fighter/2 Monk (for robes and skill dump) for the OC would it be gimp completely?
 
Pally? Not much really. There is little a pally can do that cleric can't do better except for smiting. Pallies are better implemented as CHA-based synergies for DM/DS builds. Yes, saves will be slightly better, but at what cost?  Negative Energy Protection is a must-have vs. shadows and other drain attacks.  Hammer of the Gods and Word of Faith are two of the most effective mob-control spells in the game.  Battletide has a double combat bonus that not only increases your AB by 2 but also your effective AC by the same amount besides the boost to saves.  And you are going to love Empowered Healing Circle when surrounded by undead.

Holy Sword was nerfed badly by v1.69 so a caster level 10 dispel for half the hits is hardly worth investing heavily to achieve.  Besides, the enhancement is still bugged so when the spell wears off your +10 weapon will be hitting as a +5 one until you un-equip/re-equip.  On the positive side, pally can empower Bull and Eagle just as a cleric can but like I said, CHA-based builds are better for pally for long durations of damage and AC boosts.  A cleric can access AoV with War Domain, if you feel it may be difficult to reach ability caps.

It's not so much of a gimp (though it is to some degree) as it is a lack of versatility to face many situations with the same degree of competence.  But then, if you are not comfortable with extensive self-buffing (many players fall into this category), I can understand the hesitancy.  Cleric simply has more potential but both are feat-starved classes so that aspect is a wash. The other factor is that focusing more into WIS actually gains high-level spells for a cleric whereas a pally has little need for WIS over 14, especially with a STR-focus.  A cleric self-buffing Empowered Owl will gain +3 AC by virtue of the monk synergy where a pally is limited to Clvl 3 pots.
and for the level 40 build where I can reach lvl 20 monk I think there is no need for divine spell casting restriction since lvl 20 monk looks superhuman enough for the "Jedi", is it better or worse to make monk/fighter/wm(katana) than mentioned monk/cleric/fighter or it would be just different?
Keep in mind that all your classes will be developing slowly to avoid XP penalty.  Monk 20 won't happen until level 40 with all the alternating.
The more I think about paladin/monk the more I like it RP wise for jedi knight (although cleric/fighter/monk suit for jedi consular)
You might like the idea for its RP value but it will be weaker than the cleric/monk by far. Gut "feelings" and kewlness can become expensive when it comes to optimizing a build.  However, if you would like to see an example for your own edification I can piece one together.

At the risk of wading into deeper water than intended, if you want to invest at least 20 levels of Monk into a build, then you should really be thinking of either dual-wielding kamas (which you could view as two half light sabres at a push) or going unarmed. You wouldn't be able to take fist as your Weapon of Choice, so WM would have to fall by the wayside if you went with that option, but you could do it with kamas. Either way, taking katana would severely gimp you, with little or no reward.

However, if you're dead set on a katana build but flexible on classes, Empyre has come up with a couple of great ones in the aforementioned Aielund thread, which you might want to have a look at. One is a Fighter/Bard/WM, the other a Fighter/Bard/RDD. And let's remember, it's not what you call yourself, it's what you do that counts.

I suspect there are good resonances between Monk and Pally, but would probably look at CoT rather than Cleric as my third class. Others will know better.

posts.author: HipRedux
posts.content:
Stagmeister wrote:
At the risk of wading into deeper water than intended, if you want to invest at least 20 levels of Monk into a build, then you should really be thinking of either dual-wielding kamas (which you could view as two half light sabres at a push) or going unarmed. You wouldn't be able to take fist as your Weapon of Choice, so WM would have to fall by the wayside if you went with that option, but you could do it with kamas. Either way, taking katana would severely gimp you, with little or no reward.
Let's try to quantify the exact compromises of certain preferences when integrating the monk class.  The class can be used for more than just skill dumps (classic Mnk 6), DW kama build or UBAB.

Using non-monk weapons will use the standard -5 BAB progression.  Yes, it's a concilation, but isn't it amazing how many builds do so well with the standard progression? 

You'll be able to reach 5 APR with a combo of Divine Power and Haste while the monk's kama APR (hasted w/DP) would be 7, with the free attacks (DP/haste) using the standard -5 progression.  The katana version will always be using full AB since both DWing and FoB reduce it by at least -2 and another -2, respectively (i.e. DW w/FoB -4 AB).  Once you begin to factor all the quick spam attacks into the mix, suddenly that lofty -3 progression begins to approach and then fade behind the katana.  High APR is better for DevCrit than damage per round vs high AC because your chances of a natural 20 increase dramatically on any of the attacks.

When using DP, BAB < 16 is ALWAYS the optimization.  Here's a revisit to those who may have forgotten or never realized it:

(We'll assuming a STR-focused build in both cases to make this easier to quantify.)

Sample #1: BAB >/= 16 (4 APR)
Before DP: +30/+25/+20/+15
During DP: +30/+25/+20/+15

Sample #2: BAB 11 thru 15 (3 APR)
Before DP: +30/+25/+20
During DP: +30/+25/+20/+30

Sample #3: BAB 6 thru 10 (2 APR)
Before DP: +30/+25
During DP: +30/+25/+30/+25

...which is why a DP build should always stay below BAB 16 to reap the best AB.   So, a sorc or wiz with enough cleric levels to access DP can actually hit better than a fighter.

So... then what EXACTLY will be gained by a toon wielding just a katana in robes that reaches Monk 20?

Combat Feats: Cleave, KD/IKD
Intrinsic Characteristics: deflection of missiles w/Refl 20 min, immune to half-damage reflex spells (most evoc school), immunity to poison/disease/mind spells, non-breachable SR 30, +4 monk AC, 160% move speed
Activations: limited self-healing, limited 50% concealment

Still sounds like a pretty good deal to me even without kamas or bare fists.

As far as trying to force-feed WM into all these personal biases and RP constraints just to expand the crit range and increase damage on crit, IMO it is act of futility.  There are too many prereqs for WM that could have been used for useful combat enhancements.  If you want to knock yourself out to prove it to yourself, then start designing. It will be an education at least. Figure on a minimum of WM 19 to make it at all worthwhile.   I've never been a fan of the WM 5 or WM 7 builds because they cater too much to killing easy foes quickly while never gaining any better competency vs. bosses.  I'd pass on this idea if you want to focus on the most productive sort of builds rather than those that just seem kewl.
